titlestmt.title: The Whore of Babylon : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 9KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 140KB to 1100KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and ArchivesMarch 2011
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of thirty-three of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. All take their subjects from the New Testament and have been added to the twenty Old Testament subjects published in March 2010 as “Illustrations to the Bible, c. 1780-1824,” under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings. This new group is presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
Blake executed most of these New Testament water colors c. 1800-05 for his patron Thomas Butts. The exceptions are The Whore of Babylon of 1809 and The Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins in the Yale Center for British Art, datable to c. 1825. The subjects range from the childhood of Jesus to his ascension, the later history of his parents and one of his major followers, St. Paul, and a group of eight designs based on the Book of Revelation. While the illustrations of the life of Christ are fairly conventional in their subjects, in part because of the long tradition of picturing almost every event in the Gospels, individual motifs recall designs in Blake’s illuminated books and thus offer a window on Blake’s visual interpretation of the Bible. The illustrations of Revelation complement Blake’s intense engagement with apocalyptic events and images in his own poetry.
The selection of fifty-three biblical water colors now available in the Archive will be supplemented in the future with early works, such as Abraham and Isaac, datable to c. 1780, and will continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, such as Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color
objinfo.support: card-like paperThe paper is probably a heavy wove.
objinfo.framelines: A single framing line is contiguous with the edge of the design on all four sides.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.dealer: Evans (probably either Edward Evans or R. H. Evans)
provenance.note: Probably commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts in 1809 as a late addition to the series of biblical water colors; probably the work offered by A. E. Evans & Son, 1845 catalogue part III, item 723, "a very Curious Coloured Drawing, illustrating the Revelations by this original Artist [Blake], *signed and dated* 1809" (£2.12s.6d.); sold by Evans in 1847 to the British Museum.

repository.addressline: Email, Department of Prints and Drawings: prints@britishmuseum.org
URL, Department of Prints and Drawings: http://www.britishmuseum.org/the_museum/departments/prints_and_drawings.aspx

objnote.p: Blake signed and dated the work lower left; see the textual transcription.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is based on Revelation 17:1-4. In the center of the design sits the female figure of the Whore of Babylon, facing forward and with her lower body facing slightly left and her upper body facing slightly right. She wears a skirt with a jagged hem, possibly decorated with jewels. She wears anklets and two necklaces, one of pearls or beads and one chain with a heart pendant. She also wears two bracelets on each wrist and a three-tiered crown on her head. Her upper body is nude and her breasts are exposed. She has long curly hair, slightly flame-like, and sits with her legs bent and knees drawn slightly up, legs crossed at the ankles. Her left arm is raised at 45 degrees and points down and to the left. Her right arm is raised at 45 degrees and bent upward. In her right hand she holds a goblet or chalice. It is wrapped around with two scaly snakes, the left one facing right and up and the right one facing left and up. On the goblet are columns topped by arches and four gowned figures of indeterminable gender standing with their arms raised at 135 degrees, facing forward, left, and right. They may be dancing. A cloud (of smoke?) issues from the goblet. Within the cloud are seven flying nude female figures with long hair. The leftmost figure faces away and to the right. Her right leg is bent back. Her left arm is raised vertically and her right arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent to hold an indeterminable object, perhaps a vase or pitcher, above her head as she rises upward. The second-to-left figure faces forward and up, with her lower body facing left and her upper body facing right. Her legs are bent, with her right leg extended backward. Her right arm is raised vertically and her left arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent upward. In her right hand she holds a horn or trumpet that she presumably plays. In her right hand she holds what appears to be a goblet or glass. The third-to-left figure faces away and to the right, bending forward. Her legs are bent with her right leg extended backward. Her arms are raised at 135 degrees and bent; in her hands she holds what appears to be a large goblet or a bowl. The middle figure of this group faces forward, right and down. Her right leg is bent and extended back. Her arms are raised at 135 degrees and crossed to hold a large bowl with what may be a flame rising from it. The third-to-right figure faces away, right and up. Her left leg is bent. Her left arm is raised vertically and in her left hand she holds a horn or trumpet which she presumably plays. Her right arm is raised vertically and bent and in her right hand she may hold a goblet. The second-to-right figure faces forward, left and down. She is partly upside down. Her arms are raised horizontally and in her right hand she holds a goblet; in her left hand, she holds a horn or trumpet, which she presumably plays. The rightmost figure is upside down and faces down and right. Her right arm is raised vertically and her left arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent. In her hands she holds what appears to be a large goblet. The Whore of Babylon rides on the nude male figure of her "beast" (Revelation 17:3). He appears to have feathers or fur around his hips and shoulders, as well as a crest of spiky fins along his spine. He faces left and down, crouching on the ground with his legs and arms bent. His feet and hands have claws for nails and are bestial. His dark veins are particularly pronounced in his hands and neck. The figure has seven heads, all male with short, curly hair and horns surrounded by spiky crowns. The leftmost head faces left and down and has a pointed ear. The next head above faces left and down and has a pointy ear. The lowest head faces left and down and has looped horns like a ram's. His mouth is open with his teeth visible. He may be eating a nude human. The head just above the lowest head looks down and to the left, facing forward slightly; its mouth is open with its teeth visible. The head just above and slightly to the left faces forward, up, and right, perhaps looking at the Whore of Babylon. The highest head has a pug nose and faces forward, looking up and to the right, perhaps looking at the Whore of Babylon. The rightmost head appears to be old and has a beard; he faces forward and looks up and to the right, perhaps at the figures emanating from the Whore of Babylon's urn. His mouth is open and his upper teeth are visible. The scene takes place against the backdrop of a clear sky, with a wash that may suggest sunrise or sunset. A hill or distant mountain may rise from right to left behind the figures. The earth at the bottom of the design appears to be bare, with a large rock that the beast kneels on. There may be a line of low hills extending right to left across the design. In the foreground to the left of the beast's legs are at least eight figures. Most appear to be fighting soldiers. The leftmost figure is that of an armored soldier, standing, facing away and slightly left. His arms are raised at 135 degrees and bent upward and he holds a flag. He may look at the beast. The second-to-left figure is that of an armored soldier holding a sword in his right hand and a shield in his left hand. He faces forward and to the right, bending forward slightly. His right leg is extended back and his left leg is bent. Both legs may be on tiptoe. To the right of this soldier, two figures are visible in the background as sketchy heads. The third-to-right figure is an armored soldier, facing right and away. He stands on his right foot, which is extended back, while his left leg is bent. In his left hand he holds a shield and in his right hand he holds a spear. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees and bent. The second-to-right figure is visible only as a nude lower body, facing forward and right. He(?) is being eaten by the beast. The rightmost figure of this group is that of a gowned female, standing with her lower body facing left and her upper body twisted to face forward, right, and up. Her right arm is at her side but bent and in her right hand she holds a goblet. Her left arm is raised at 135 degrees and in her right hand she holds a trumpet or horn that she presumably plays. In the foreground in the bottom left corner of the design is a pile of at least five bodies. The second-to-right figure faces forward and up, but the rest face down and right or left. They are all probably dead. In the background between the beast's head and front legs stand at least six sketchy figures, just visible as heads. The three leftmost may stand facing right and the three rightmost may stand facing left or away. At least five spears are visible, held by members of this group. In the foreground between the beast's front leg and back leg are at least seven figures and two horses. The leftmost figure is an armored soldier, facing right and away. He kneels or crouches with his left leg extended backward and his right leg bent and drawn slightly up. His right arm is at his side but bent upward and he holds a spear, looking at the soldier to his right. The second-to-left figure faces forward and may sit, head back and mouth open. It is of indeterminable gender, but may be gowned. The third-to-left figure is that of an armored soldier, facing left and slightly forward. He stands with his legs bent and his left leg extended backward and on tiptoe. His arms are at his side and bent, with his right arm bent upward. He holds a spear and is looking at the soldier to his left. The middle figure is visible only as a head, facing left. The third-to-right figure lies, supine, and is of indeterminable gender. Its legs are bent and its right arm is bent, and it may lean on this arms. It faces forward and to the right, and looks up with its mouth open. It may be armored or wear a hood. The second-to-right figure lies with its body horizontal, facing forward and left. It is of indeterminable gender, but may be gowned. The front horse faces left and up, rearing up or leaping. Its legs are bent and extended and its head is slightly down. It wears reins and is pulling a chariot. The second horse appears just behind the front horse. The rightmost figure is an armored soldier sitting and riding in a chariot. He faces forward and right and looks up. His left leg is bent and he leans back slightly. His right arm is at his side but bent and in his left hand he holds a spear. His right arm is raised horizontally and bent upward slightly; in his right hand, he holds a goblet. To the right of the beast's rear leg are at least two figures, one on the ground and one in the air. The figure on the ground may be sitting or crouching and bending forward. It is of indeterminable gender, but has its legs bent and its left arm raised horizontally with its hand on the ground. It faces left and down and is hunched over. The figure in the air faces down, left, and away as it hovers or descends. It appears to be nude and is of indeterminable gender. Its right leg is bent and its arms are raised vertically. The figure plays two trumpets or horns held in its hands.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the design sits the female figure of the Whore of Babyon, facing forward and with her lower body facing slightly left and her upper body facing slightly right. She wears a skirt with a jagged hem. She wears anklets and two necklaces, one of pearls or beads and one chain with a heart pendant. She also wears two bracelets on each wrist, pearl drop earrings, and a three-tiered crown on her head. Her upper body is nude and her breasts are exposed. She has long curly hair, slightly flame-like, and sits with her legs bent and knees drawn slightly up and legs crossed at the ankles. Her left arm is raised at 45 degrees and points down and to the left. Her right arm is raised at 45 degrees and bent upward. In her right hand she holds an urn or vase.

The Whore of Babylon holds in her right hand a golden goblet or chalice. It is wrapped around with two scaly snakes, the left one facing right and up and the right one facing left and up. On the goblet are columns topped by arches and four gowned figures of indeterminable gender standing with their arms raised at 135 degrees, facing forward, left, and right. They may be dancing.
A cloud (of smoke?) issues from the goblet held by the Whore of Babylon. The cloud arches over her head.

From the goblet held by the Whore of Babylon issue seven flying nude female figures with long hair. The leftmost figure faces away and to the right. Her right leg is bent back. Her left arm is raised vertically and her right arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent to hold an indeterminable object, perhaps a vase or pitcher, above her head as she rises upward.

From the goblet held by the Whore of Babylon issue seven flying nude female figures with long hair. The second-to-left figure faces forward and up, with her lower body facing left and her upper body facing right. Her legs are bent, with her right leg extended backward. Her right arm is raised vertically and her left arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent upward. In her left hand she holds a horn or trumpet that she presumably plays. In her right hand she holds what appears to be a goblet or glass.

From the goblet held by the Whore of Babylon issue seven flying nude female figures with long hair. The third-to-left figure faces away and to the right, bending forward. Her legs are bent with her right leg extended backward. Her arms are raised at 135 degrees and bent; in her hands she holds what appears to be a large goblet or a bowl.

From the goblet held by the Whore of Babylon issue seven flying nude female figures with long hair. The middle figure of this group faces forward, right and down. Her right leg is bent and extended back. Her arms are raised at 135 degrees and crossed to hold a large bowl with what may be a flame rising from it.

From the goblet held by the Whore of Babylon issue seven flying nude female figures with long hair. The third-to-right figure faces away, right and up. Her left leg is bent. Her left arm is raised vertically and in her left hand she holds a horn or trumpet which she presumably plays. Her right arm is raised vertically and bent and in her right hand she may hold a goblet. She appears to be falling or descending.

From the goblet held by the Whore of Babylon issue seven flying nude female figures with long hair. The second-to-right figure faces forward, left and down. She is partly upside down. Her arms are raised horizontally and in her right hand she holds a goblet; in her left hand, she holds a horn or trumpet, which she presumably plays. She appears to be falling or descending.

From the goblet held by the Whore of Babylon issue seven flying nude female figures with long hair. The rightmost figure is upside down and faces down and right. Her right arm is raised vertically and her left arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent. In her hands she holds what appears to be a large goblet. She appears to be falling or descending.

The Whore of Babylon rides on the nude male figure of her "beast" (Revelation 17:3). He appears to have feathers or fur around his hips and shoulders, as well as a crest of spiky fins along his spine. He faces left and down, crouching on the ground with his legs and arms bent. His feet and hands have claws for nails and are bestial. His dark veins are particularly pronounced in his hands and neck. The figure has seven heads, all male with short, curly hair and horns surrounded by spiky crowns. The leftmost head faces left and down and has a pointed ear. The next head above faces left and down and has a pointy ear. The lowest head faces left and down and has looped horns like a ram's. His mouth is open with his teeth visible. He may be eating a nude human. The head just above the lowest head looks down and to the left, facing forward slightly; its mouth is open with its teeth visible. The head just above and slightly to the left faces forward, up, and right, perhaps looking at the Whore of Babylon. The highest head has a pug nose and faces forward, looking up and to the right, perhaps looking at the Whore of Babylon. The rightmost head appears to be old and has a beard; he faces forward and looks up and to the right, perhaps at the figures emanating from the Whore of Babylon's urn. His mouth is open and his upper teeth are visible.

In the foreground to the left of the beast's legs are at least eight figures. Most appear to be fighting soldiers. The leftmost figure is that of an armored soldier, standing, facing away and slightly left. His arms are raised at 135 degrees and bent upward and he holds a flag. He may look at the beast.

In the foreground to the left of the beast's legs are at least eight figures. Most appear to be fighting soldiers. The second-to-left figure is that of an armored soldier holding a sword in his right hand and a shield in his left hand. He faces forward and to the right, bending forward slightly. His right leg is extended back and his left leg is bent. Both legs may be on tiptoe. His mouth may be partly open.

In the foreground to the left of the beast's legs are at least eight figures. Most appear to be fighting soldiers. The third-to-left, fourth-to-left, and fourth-to-right figures are visible in the background as sketchy heads. They may be intended to suggest a crowd in the background.

In the foreground to the left of the beast's legs are at least eight figures. Most appear to be fighting soldiers. The third-to-right figure is an armored soldier, facing right and away. He stands on his right foot, which is extended back, while his left leg is bent. In his left hand he holds a shield and in his right hand he holds a spear. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees and bent.

In the foreground to the left of the beast's legs are at least eight figures. The second-to-right figure is visible only as a nude lower body, facing forward and right. He(?) is being eaten by the beast.

In the foreground to the left of the beast's legs are at least eight figures. The rightmost figure of this group is that of a gowned female, standing with her lower body facing left and her upper body twisted to face forward, right, and up. Her right arm is at her side but bent and in her right hand she holds a goblet. Her left arm is raised at 135 degrees and in her right hand she holds a trumpet or horn that she presumably plays.

In the foreground in the bottom left corner of the design is a pile of at least five bodies. The second-to-right figure faces forward and up, but the rest face down and right or left. They are all probably dead soldiers.

In the background between the beast's head and front legs stand at least six sketchy figures, just visible as heads. The three leftmost may stand facing right and the three rightmost may stand facing left or away. At least five spears are visible, held by members of this group.

In the foreground between the beast's front leg and back leg are at least seven figures and two horses. The leftmost figure is an armored soldier, facing right and away. He kneels or crouches with his left leg extended backward and his right leg bent and drawn slightly up. His right arm is at his side but bent upward and he holds a spear, looking at the soldier to his right.

In the foreground between the beast's front leg and back leg are at least seven figures and two horses. The second-to-left figure faces forward and may sit, head back and mouth open. It is of indeterminable gender, but may be gowned and is probably another soldier.

In the foreground between the beast's front leg and back leg are at least seven figures and two horses. The third-to-left figure is that of an armored soldier, facing left and slightly forward. He stands with his legs bent and his left leg extended backward and on tiptoe. His arms are at his side and bent, with his right arm bent upward. He holds a spear and is looking at the soldier to his left.
In the foreground between the beast's front leg and back leg are at least seven figures and two horses. The middle figure is visible only as a head, perhaps facing left.

In the foreground between the beast's front leg and back leg are at least seven figures and a horse. The third-to-right figure lies, supine, and is of indeterminable gender. Its legs are bent and its right arm is bent, and it may lean on this arms. It faces forward and to the right, and looks up with its mouth open. It may be armored or wear a hood.

In the foreground between the beast's front leg and back leg are at least seven figures and two horses. The second-to-right figure lies with its body horizontal, facing forward and left. It is of indeterminable gender, but may be gowned. Its arms may be wrapped around its head.

In the foreground between the beast's front leg and back leg are at least seven figures and two horses. The front horse faces left and up, rearing up or leaping. Its legs are bent and extended and its head is slightly down. It wears reins and pulls a chariot. A second horse appears just behind the front one.

In the foreground between the beast's front leg and back leg are at least seven figures and two horses. The rightmost figure is an armored soldier sitting and riding in a wheeled chariot. The armor over his chest appears to be scaly. He faces forward and right and looks up. His left leg is bent and he leans back slightly. His right arm is at his side but bent and in his left hand he holds a spear. His right arm is raised horizontally and bent upward slightly; in his right hand, he holds a goblet.
Two horses pull and wheeled chariot.

To the right of the beast's rear leg are at least two figures, one on the ground and one in the air. The figure on the ground may be sitting or crouching and bending forward. It is of indeterminable gender, but has its legs bent and its left arm raised horizontally with its hand on the ground. It faces left and down and is hunched over.

To the right of the beast's rear leg are at least two figures, one on the ground and one in the air. The figure in the air faces down, left, and away as it hovers or descends. It appears to be nude and is of indeterminable gender. Its right leg is bent and its arms are raised vertically. The figure plays two trumpets or horns held in its hands.
The scene takes place against the backdrop of a clear sky, with a wash that may suggest sunrise or sunset. A hill or distant mountain may rise from right to left behind the figures.
The earth at the bottom of the design appears to be bare, with a large rock that the beast kneels on. There may be a line of low hills extending right and left across the design.
